{"seo": [], "title": "Sports betting- A snowball that has engulfed many Kenyans in the hope of making quick cash", "years": ["2016"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q1"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Tue-03-2016", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "15th Mar, 2016", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "italic"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "NAIROBI, KENYA: Nothing has gained traction in Kenya faster than sports betting – the expensive hobby that has taken off and snowballed into a sensation. Thanks to the gambling phenomenon, “prediction” is now a household name among millions of Kenyans out to hit the jackpot and strike a fortune.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "It is estimated by now that about 23 companies have been licensed as operators of the new and obviously lucrative gambling business.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Applications from many more are at various stages of consideration before approvals are granted, according to the Betting Control and Licensing Board (BCLB).", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "mCHEZA, a firm associated with Julie Gichuru, the hugely successful TV personality, is the latest operator to be approved only this month.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“We have invested in lottery. Gaming (betting) is the newest passion in local sports. It is interesting to bet but you shouldn’t be addicted,” Gichuru is quoted to have said after unveiling the business.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "However far from her caution to prospective players, most of the estimated 2 million gamers in Kenya – according to modest estimates, could have long been addicted to betting.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Not a single independent study has valued the worth of sport betting in Kenya, perhaps because it just hit the tipping point, but everyone including internet café operators agrees it has exploded.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Gamers who do not own smart phones will drop by such cafes to learn about the upcoming games, the participants and their winning record. Call it appraising the horse they are placing their money on!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Sports Cabinet Secretary Hassan Wario believes the entry of global betting giants including Betways – the sponsors of the English Premier League club West Ham, and Greek’s Intralot, only confirmed the size of the emerging industry and its potential value.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“The betting industry has not been formally evaluated in terms of its actual monetary worth, but it runs into billions of shillings if properly exploited,” Mr Wario said. It has remained a largely lackluster sector for decades until last year, even when in the neighboring Uganda it has been big business for over a decade.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“The entry of big players and the diversification of the betting products could most certainly attract more customers and increase the revenue,” added the CS, who projects that the growth momentum will be sustained.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "He acknowledges that the number of active gamers is huge, but could not immediately provide a number until later in the week when the statistics are collated from the almost two-dozen operators.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "An official at the BCLB said it was common for users to be signed up across the various platforms, suggesting that the operator with the largest subscriber base of about 2 million is a fair estimate of gamers in Kenya.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "About 300,000 users play for the multi-shilling jackpot every week, according to an insider in one of the operators, where each gamer bets Sh100 per set.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "It is common for users to bet on different several combinations of wins, draws and losses for the target games, so as to increase the chances of landing on the right combination.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "A middle-aged man identified himself as Mwenda when we approached him, and shared his lucky and not-so lucky escapades in the craze of sport betting. Despite never hitting the jackpot in the 10 months he has been actively betting, every weekend is a thrill as he and his fellowship of gamers literally get down to business of making predictions.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“We have not won yet and we are doing that even tomorrow,” Mwenda says. The closest they have come to a win in the jackpot is 7 correct predictions out of the set of 13 matches. In the Sportpesa gaming platform, for instance, a gamer who gets 10 correct predictions in the set wins a tidy sum, often more than Sh70,000.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "That amount is however tiny, when compared to the jackpot that can be as high as Sh30 million. Lotto, another operator that re-entered the country in November announced an unprecedented jackpot amount of Sh100 million.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "By whichever measures, hitting the jackpot will certainly be life-changing and is an allure most cannot ignore.", "type": "text"}, {"type": "hardBreak"}, {"text": "For many of these gamers, betting has become an everyday event that involves games, some so bizarre such as ice hockey and greyhound racing. Yet, some of the games would be played in countries like Iceland – which an ordinary Kenyan would struggle to locate on the World map.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "A comment posted on social network days before last Christmas, perhaps perfectly captures the sensation that gaming has become. “Sport betting in Kenya looks like the new girl in class,” a user identified as Waweru Njogu posted on his Twitter account, excitement of gaming to that shared by (possibly teenage) boys on arrival of a new female student in their class.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The excitement and addiction is fueled by the adrenaline rush of betting, the suspense in waiting for the games to end and the satisfaction of winning, often after many hours where several matches are involved.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“Disappointments are normal, but I always look back to the time I won big for consolation,” said a bank manager who requested anonymity, revealing that he once walked away with Sh72,000 from an investment of Sh100.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "His win came three years ago in an outlet housed by the former Odeon Cinema Building along Nairobi’s Tom Mboya Street.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "An in-house survey has revealed the popularity of sport betting, aided in part by ease of placing a bet through a combination of letters, numbers and alphanumeric characters punched on the mobile phone.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "All one needs to play is to be a registered user with any of the 23 service providers, and have money in their virtual wallets.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Sportpesa, the firm thought to be having the biggest number of registered users in the country, revealed that its more than 1.5 million active subscribers to its service. An official of the firm said the number could actually be higher today as the numbers were from earlier last week.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "It has been an unprecedented growth, David Akungah who had resisted placing his first bet and has since become a regular gambler.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“I have spent a lot in betting but I am lucky to have won even more,” Mr Akungah, a mechanical technician, said while acknowledging that most of the other gamblers he knows in person have lost.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "He has spent a total of Sh12, 000 and earned more than Sh18, 500, from the account statements from the virtual wallet. “I am in the money still,” he added, indicating that he would keep playing in anticipation of landing on the big win.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "One source of inspiration for Akungah, and many other gamers, is businessman George Mwangi who hit Sh29.6 million win in September.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Mwangi, a confessed fan of domestic soccer league holders Gor Mahia, revealed that he had played many times before striking the fortune.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "He, like many gamers, kept a close tally of all his expenditure as if it would make any difference if he never won. In total, his cumulative bets were worth Sh16,000 over the previous many months. Even then, he had still won smaller amounts but this specific win was unprecedented.", "type": "text"}]}], "article_image": "sports-betting-1727340362.png", "back_cta_link": "entry::3237", "article_excerpt": "NAIROBI, KENYA: Nothing has gained traction in Kenya faster than sports betting – the expensive hobby that has taken off and snowballed into a sensation. Thanks to the gambling phenomenon, “prediction” is now a household name among millions of Kenyans out to hit the jackpot and strike a fortune.", "blog_categories": ["trending"], "article_location": "Lorem Ipsum", "article_subtitle": null, "article_back_to_text": "Back to Blogs", "article_banner_image": "sports-betting.png", "enable_article_subtitle": null, "home_slider_banner_image": null, "enable_article_home_slider": false}

{"seo": [], "title": "World Bank: Developing countries yet to benefit from digital growth", "years": ["2016"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q1"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Thu-03-2016", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "17th Mar, 2016", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "italic"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "NAIROBI, KENYA", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "bold"}]}, {"text": ": World Bank has challenged developing nations to improve their business environment by increasing access to Internet and promoting good governance so as to reap the benefits of Information and Communication Technologies.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "In a report dubbed ‘World Development Report 2016: Digital Dividends’, the bank notes the potential of modern technologies in delivering jobs, crucial services such as identification, and money transfer in areas previously unimagined.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "It for instance cites Kenya as a nation where modern technologies has assisted her citizens to cut cost in money remittances through the M-Pesa technology. Other developing countries mentioned in the report such as India have also harnessed technologies in job creation through business and outsourcing processes.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“In Kenya, for example, the cost of sending remittances dropped by up to 90 percent after the introduction of M-Pesa, a digital payment system,” says Jim Yong Kim President The World Bank Group", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“New technologies have also helped women to participate more easily in the labor market as ecommerce entrepreneurs, in online work, or in business-process outsourcing. The world’s 1 billion persons with disabilities-80 percent of whom live in developing countries can lead more productive lives with the help of text, voice, and video communication,” he says.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The World Bank President notes that those in extreme poverty have the most to gain from better communication and access to information which requires input from the authorities in charge.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "He calls on governments within developing countries to improve their business climate, invest in people’s education and health, and promote good governance.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "He says in countries where these fundamentals are weak, digital technologies have not boosted productivity or reduced inequality. “Countries that complement technology investments with broader economic reforms reap digital dividends in the form of faster growth, more jobs, and better services,” the President says.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "According to the ‘World Development Report 2016: Digital Dividends’ report a total of four billion people, representing 60 per cent of the world’s population remains excluded from the ever-expanding digital economy.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The report conducted by co-directors, Deepak Mishra and Uwe Deichmann and team says the benefits of rapid digital expansion have been skewed towards the wealthy, skilled, and influential around the world, which are better positioned to take advantage of the new technologies.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "In addition, though the number of internet users worldwide has more than tripled since 2005, four billion people still lack access to the internet.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“Digital technologies are transforming the worlds of business, work, and government,” said Deepak Mishra.", "type": "text"}, {"type": "hardBreak"}, {"text": "He added, “We must continue to connect everyone and leave no one behind because the cost of lost opportunities is enormous. But for digital dividends to be widely shared among all parts of society, countries also need to improve their business climate, invest in people’s education and health, and promote good governance.”", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Although there are many individual success stories, the effect of technology on global productivity, expansion of opportunity for the poor and middle class, and the spread of accountable governance has so far been less than expected.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Digital technologies are spreading rapidly, but digital dividends – growth, jobs and services – have lagged behind.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“The digital revolution is transforming the world, aiding information flows, and facilitating the rise of developing nations that are able to take advantage of these new opportunities,” said Kaushik Basu, World Bank Chief Economist.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "He added, “It is an amazing transformation that today 40 percent of the world’s population is connected by the internet. While these achievements are to be celebrated, this is also occasion to be mindful that we do not create a new underclass. With nearly 20 per cent of the world’s population unable to read and write, the spread of digital technologies alone is unlikely to spell the end of the global knowledge divide.”", "type": "text"}]}], "article_image": "world-bank-1727340517.jpg", "back_cta_link": "entry::3237", "article_excerpt": "NAIROBI, KENYA: World Bank has challenged developing nations to improve their business environment by increasing access to Internet and promoting good governance so as to reap the benefits of Information and Communication Technologies.", "blog_categories": ["trending"], "article_location": "Lorem Ipsum", "article_subtitle": null, "article_back_to_text": "Back to Blogs", "article_banner_image": "world-bank.jpg", "enable_article_subtitle": null, "home_slider_banner_image": null, "enable_article_home_slider": false}

{"seo": [], "title": "KCB Group changing the narrative in Youth unemployment", "years": ["2016"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q2"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Wed-04-2016", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "13th Apr, 2016", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "italic"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Several studies released in the past indicate Kenya needs to create more jobs for its youths to accommodate high number graduating yearly from colleges and universities.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "In 2015 for example, SAP and Endeavour (a global nonprofit organization) said Kenya needs to create more than 3.9 million jobs for a workforce projected to be at 3.4 million by the year 2020, due primarily to young adults entering the job market.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "A new project by KCB Bank Kenya Limited and like-minded partners offers a ray of hope to thousands of youth currently jobless in the country.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "On March 9 at a gathering which included US ambassador to Kenya, Robert Godec, government officials, industrialists and governors among other leaders, KCB said it has a Sh50 billion plan to help fight youth unemployment in the country.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The bank through the programme dubbed 2jiajiri said it will create approximately 2.5 million direct and indirect jobs into the Kenyan economy by working with 500,000 youths in selected sectors such as agricultural enterprise, automotive engineering, construction, beauty and domestic services.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The 2jiaijiri programme is a follow-up of the commitment the bank made during the Global Entrepreneurship Summit (GES) in July 2015 when it pledged to boost its investments in entrepreneurship.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Through its Foundation, the bank has roped in Government Ministries, industry players, development partners and private companies. It is working with more than 89 County Governments’ vocational institutions in the country to enroll students for this programme. On the industry front, Toyota Kenya, Naivas Supermarkets, Chandaria Industries and East African Portland Cement have agreed to facilitate the distribution opportunity for beneficiaries upon completion of their courses.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "KCB Group Chairman Ngeny Biwott said the programme fits well within Kenya government’s resolve to boost youth employment, potentially raising country’s economic prospects.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“We believe that through partnerships with organizations, we can redefine the youth unemployment challenges we are facing,” said Mr. Biwott.  “We are committing to changing the youth narrative in the country,” said the Chairman.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The programme targets both existing (70 percent) and potential entrepreneurs (30 percent). For existing entrepreneurs, 2Jiajiri seeks to up-skill and formalize the technical and enterprise skills of the selected youthful entrepreneurs. Upcoming entrepreneurs will receive technical skills, financial support for startups and business advisory services. Cognizant of the fact that not all are entrepreneurs, some of them will be linked to work-experience programmes to give them hands-on training while exposing them to market opportunities.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Already, 2,000 youths have begun classes in 89 institutions spread across the country for the various 3-6 months courses. After their training, the graduates will be put under a 12 months incubation programme.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“Entrepreneurship and innovation are an integral part of our DNA. We operate under innovative platforms and with an incubation programme, we will promote ideas, offer mentorship, provide concepts and methods to create an optimal environment for free enterprise,” added KCB CEO Joshua Oigara.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The bank believes that this programme will be a game changer in the country where over one million young people enter into the labour market annually without any skills some having either dropped out of school or completed school and not enrolled in any college.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "This is further compounded by the fact that almost 155,000 who join the labour market annually after completing training in Technical Vocational Education and Training Institutions or at the university to acquire skills that often do not meet the expectation of employers.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "With statistics indicating that a total of over 1.3 million new employment places need to be created annually to meet the rising demand for jobs, this initiative will take advantage of the opportunities a large youth population offers while adequately tackling the skills gap challenge facing the country. Statistics show for example that the ideal rate of Engineers: Technicians: Artisans is supposed to be 1:13:60 but Kenya is currently at 1:3:13.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "For the more tech-savvy entrepreneurs, KCB bank Kenya has created the 2Jiajiri Business Challenge. All one needs to do is register that business idea you believe is the next big thing on a portal (", "type": "text"}, {"text": "www.bankika.co.ke", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "link", "attrs": {"rel": null, "href": "http://www.bankika.co.ke/", "title": null, "target": null}}]}, {"text": ") and if your idea is chosen, you get low cost financing, incubation and mentorship. The portal has a mentorship program that gives many a chance to engage and be mentored by industry leaders.", "type": "text"}]}], "article_image": "kcbgroup-changing-the-narrative-1727341028.jpg", "back_cta_link": "entry::3237", "article_excerpt": "Several studies released in the past indicate Kenya needs to create more jobs for its youths to accommodate high number graduating yearly from colleges and universities.", "blog_categories": ["trending"], "article_location": "Lorem Ipsum", "article_subtitle": null, "article_back_to_text": "Back to Blogs", "article_banner_image": "kcbgroup-changing-the-narrative.jpg", "enable_article_subtitle": null, "home_slider_banner_image": null, "enable_article_home_slider": false}

{"seo": [], "title": "The Quest is on To Make Nairobi a Smart City by Embracing Digital Payments", "years": ["2016"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q2"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Mon-04-2016", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "18th Apr, 2016", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "italic"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Efforts to transform Nairobi into a smart city are in top gear with the County government announcing that all payments for its services will be done digitally from the beginning of the next financial year.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "This means that all payments for land rates, parking, rentals and construction approvals will be migrated to the electronic payment platform, Ejiji Pay.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Anne Lokidor, the ICT County Executive says the move which started in 2014 with the launch of the Ejiji pay platform will help slash utility bills by for example reporting hidden water leakages and also boost revenue to the county by sealing previous corruption loopholes.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "She says this is in line with keeping to global trends where major cities are adopting technology in improving services to people and boosting revenue collection.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“You may have recently heard of Smart Cities, in reference to the current global shift by the world’s cities to the digital era. From automation of home utility services, to intelligent buildings, transportation, garbage and energy management, security and healthcare; global cities are going digital and Nairobi cannot be left behind,” she says.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“The high and rapid uptake of e-payments shows Nairobians are happy with the convenience and ease with which they transact with the county government through Ejiji Pay,” said Lokidor, who oversaw the launch of e-payments portal in 2014.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Ms. Lokidor noted that license renewals for single business permits have all been migrated to the online portal already, offering a good test case for migrating all other payment services.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The ICT Executive, who is also in charge of the Education, Social Services and Youth docket, said a special help desk will be set up to assist those who may have difficulties opening e-accounts once manual payments come to an end.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "An estimated 69,000 businesses have already renewed their single business permits for 2016 ahead of this month’s deadline. This is more than half of the about 112,000 businesses registered on the portal that is powered by IT company Web Tribe Ltd.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Ms. Lokidor said the County government has also stepped up training on use of the e-portal, working with groups such as Matatu Saccos which make monthly parking payments to the county.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“No one will be left behind, we will make compliance easy and assist those who have difficulties, but really we have to move over from the manual payments which are cumbersome and an avenue for revenue leakage,” said Ms. Lokidor, while encouraging those making payments this year to open the electronic accounts.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The migration of parking payments to the electronic platform has been the biggest driver of uptake of the e-payments, since one only needs to open a single account to pay for any other services. The county currently uses both manual and e-payments in parallel. One third (about 31 per cent) of all payments to City Hall are now made through the electronic system. The majority of seasonal parking payers (85 per cent) have migrated to the e-portal, 70 per cent of those paying parking penalties do so electronically while 100 per cent of business permits are renewed on the portal.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Overall, the County revenue collection increased 14 per cent equivalent to Sh1.3 billion in the 2014/15 financial year, a feat largely attributed to the introduction of Ejiji Pay.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Where manual forms are still the predominant form of payment, revenue growth has been steady (average increase 6.3 per cent), but where payments have shifted to Ejiji Pay, revenue growth has shot up significantly (average plus 30 per cent).", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Payers of land rates, housing and market rentals as well as construction permits have been the most hesitant to migrate to the electronic platform and the Nairobi County government is working on a sensitization campaign for this category of payers.", "type": "text"}]}], "article_image": "embracing-digital-payment-1727341179.jpg", "back_cta_link": "entry::3237", "article_excerpt": "Efforts to transform Nairobi into a smart city are in top gear with the County government announcing that all payments for its services will be done digitally from the beginning of the next financial year.", "blog_categories": ["trending"], "article_location": "Lorem Ipsum", "article_subtitle": null, "article_back_to_text": "Back to Blogs", "article_banner_image": "embracing-digital-payment.jpg", "enable_article_subtitle": null, "home_slider_banner_image": null, "enable_article_home_slider": false}

{"seo": [], "title": "Economic Crimes Surge Hampering Constructive Growth in Kenya", "years": ["2016"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q2"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Mon-04-2016", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "25th Apr, 2016", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "italic"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Local firms are among global companies losing billions due to various forms of economic crimes as documented in a report by audit firm PricewaterhouseCoopers (PWC).", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "According to the audit firm, in 2016, incidences of economic crime went up by 61 percent compared to 52 percent in 2014 which is 25 per cent above the global average.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "72 percent of the survey respondents in Kenya have experienced at least one incident of asset misappropriation in their organization, with 47 percent and 37 percent experiencing one incident of bribery and corruption and procurement fraud respectively.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "More than half of the organizations surveyed in Kenya experienced economic crime in the last two years, with cybercrime affecting a quarter of those organizations.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The PWC survey says Cybercrime is increasingly becoming a threat to organizations trying to adapt to the new digital world. Kenya’s rapid rate of growth and development especially in technology has led to the emergence of new threats presented by digital communication and hazy regulation in an increasingly integrated world. This means organizations have to come up with more innovative ways to minimize or completely eliminate these threats.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Adopting a risk based framework will allow for companies to efficiently communicate and collaborate on cybersecurity measures, both internally and externally.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "PWC Kenya released the report and commented on the global high level findings as well as in Kenya specifically as regards to changes and trends in economic crime. The survey received more than 6,000 responses from senior executives in 115 countries including 99 respondents from Kenya, representing about 15 percent of the African respondents.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "‘The global theme, which is also common from a Kenyan perspective is “Opportunity”, both in terms of the enablers of economic crime incidences and of greatest importance to organizations; how they can counter the economic crime trends through continuous and proactive measures. Investing in systems to combat economic crimes needs to go hand in hand with investing in the people that are entrusted with the assets and systems in these organizations’ said Muniu Thoithi, PWC’s Forensics Leader in Eastern Africa.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "According to the survey, most economic crimes continue to be committed by internal fraudsters who were responsible for 70 percent of the cases reported by Kenyan organizations. Customers are the primary external fraudsters with 50 percent of respondents identifying this group as the main perpetrators. Agents, intermediaries and vendors account for 10 percent each.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "‘A common assumption is that vendors have been mostly responsible for fraud, however it is the convergence of both the internal and external fraudster that poses the greatest risk to organizations’ added Muniu.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "68 percent of respondents are concerned that they will experience asset misappropriation in the next 24 months. Asset misappropriation is defined as the theft or embezzlement of company assets by directors, other fiduciaries or employees. The high incidence indicates that preventative measures, systems and controls need to be reviewed and new methods of control within organizations introduced as this form of economic crime still poses a high risk among Kenya, Africa and global respondents.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "‘A worrying trend in the survey is the low levels of confidence in local law enforcement’s ability to investigate and prosecute economic crimes. Respondents in Kenya were the least confident and most pessimistic globally at 79 percent against a global average of 44percent. The government therefore has a role in strengthening the capabilities of law enforcement agencies as well as enforcing existing legislation so as to tackle this challenge more effectively’ noted Muniu.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "According to the results of this survey, only 5 percent of respondents in Kenya reported money laundering as an economic crime experienced in their organization. It is also positive to note that 64 percent of respondents in Kenya reported that it is unlikely that the organization will experience money laundering in the next twenty four months. Given these developments, organizations in Kenya need to stay ahead of the regulatory curve by investing in the right resources to ensure they comply with all the regulatory requirements.", "type": "text"}]}], "article_image": "economics-crimes-1727341405.jpg", "back_cta_link": "entry::3237", "article_excerpt": "Local firms are among global companies losing billions due to various forms of economic crimes as documented in a report by audit firm PricewaterhouseCoopers (PWC).", "blog_categories": ["trending"], "article_location": "Lorem Ipsum", "article_subtitle": null, "article_back_to_text": "Back to Blogs", "article_banner_image": "economics-crimes.jpg", "enable_article_subtitle": null, "home_slider_banner_image": null, "enable_article_home_slider": false}

{"seo": [], "title": "New Terminal Expected to Improve Container Traffic at Mombasa Port", "years": ["2016"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q2"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Wed-04-2016", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "27th Apr, 2016", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "italic"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Container traffic through Mombasa Port is expected to increase this year after completion of first phase of the Mombasa Port Development Project.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Japan has confirmed it has completed the first phase of the Sh22 billion project which was started back in March 2012.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "In 2015, container traffic through the port grew by 7.5 percent. The facility handled 26.7 million tonnes of cargo between January and December 2015, compared to 24.88 million tonnes handled during a similar period in 2014.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Container traffic increased by 6.3 percent to 1,076,118 twenty-foot equivalent units (TEUs) in 2015 from 1,012,002 TEUs registered in 2014.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“Although this performance falls short of our target of 1.1 million TEUs for last year, it is a manifestation that the port traffic is growing at a fast rate,” acting managing director Catherine Muturi Muturi said.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Imports totaled 22.68 million tonnes, an increase of 9.2 percent from the 20.77 million tonnes handled in 2014. Exports also increased by 5 percent to 3.53 million tonnes from 3.37 million tonnes in 2014.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The volume of goods headed to neighboring countries decreased by 28.4 percent, from 731,912 tonnes in 2014 to 523,993 in 2015, a trend Muturi attributed to the introduction of a new cargo-clearing system.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Uganda remained the biggest transit market, with its cargo growing by 8.2 percent to 5.98 million tonnes in 2015, from 5.52 million tonnes in 2014.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“This year we project to handle at least 1,142,837 TEUs of cargo, which will be a remarkable growth,” said Muturi.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The port has officially received a second container terminal that had been under construction, which Muturi said would provide additional cargo-handling capacity of 550,000 TEUs per year.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Currently, Mombasa handles an average of one million containers a year, but it has a projected target of 1.32 million with the new terminal.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“This terminal has the capacity to handle 550,000 containers, which is expected to increase the capacity of the Mombasa port by over 50 per cent. On completion of the whole project, the port will become the largest in the region,” said Mombasa Port Development Project deputy manager Masati Kaneko.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Access roads, trunk roads and connection roads are fully operational, which is expected to ease cargo traffic and reduce turnaround times.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The container terminal yard at the port sits on 35 hectares and is 15 metres deep. It is able to dock an 800-tonne ship up to 50 metres high.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Over 20 million tonnes of sand and 4,000 tonnes of stones from the deep sea were excavated to create dry land and a deeper harbour. The total reclaimed volume was 3.7 million cubic metres.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "This was the major challenge, which took close to a year, Kaneko said. Prefabricated Vertical Drain (PVD) technology was used to hasten the process before soil improvements were done to make the yard more durable.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Also, to cater for the environmental impact, more than 1,500 mangrove trees were planted in Mikindani to replace those cut during construction.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The Japan International Cooperation Agency (Jica) has signed an agreement of Sh24 billion for the construction of phase two with the Kenya Ports Authority.", "type": "text"}]}], "article_image": "container-traffic-mombasa-port-1727341567.jpg", "back_cta_link": "entry::3237", "article_excerpt": "Container traffic through Mombasa Port is expected to increase this year after completion of first phase of the Mombasa Port Development Project.", "blog_categories": ["trending"], "article_location": "Lorem Ipsum", "article_subtitle": null, "article_back_to_text": "Back to Blogs", "article_banner_image": "container-traffic-mombasa-port.jpg", "enable_article_subtitle": null, "home_slider_banner_image": null, "enable_article_home_slider": false}

{"seo": [], "title": "Ray of Sunshine at last for Standard One Pupils in the Laptop Project", "years": ["2016"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q2"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Thu-05-2016", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "5th May, 2016", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "italic"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The delayed promise for 983,271 laptops for Standard One pupils has moved a step closer to reality with the selection of local universities to supply the gadgets.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "An elaborate plan, being worked on by ICT Authority under the Ministry of ICT reveals that the first batch of the devices is expected to be delivered to schools in July.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "A consortium of Moi University and JP SA Couto have already been selected to run pilot projects in 150 schools across the country, after winning the Sh17 billion laptop tender.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The schools are distributed evenly across the 47 counties with three schools picked – representing an urban, peri-urban and rural school. An additional nine schools are allotted to special education schools.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“The consortium of Moi University and JP SA Couto emerged the winner in two of the three lots which covers 26 counties whereas that of Jomo Kenyatta University of Agriculture and Technology (JKUAT) and Positivo BGH was awarded one lot covering 21 counties,” said a statement from the authority.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“The winning bidders will now proceed to demonstrate their proposals and feasibility in 150 selected schools across the 47 counties after which an evaluation will be made on whether they can start the full-scale roll out of the program across all public primary schools in the country.”", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "This means the winners will provide content for digital learning and digital devices for both learners and teachers, handle capacity development for teacher and implementers and establish local assembly for digital devices and related accessories, in addition to providing broadband connectivity.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "This is after the completion of the evaluation process of the eight suppliers who had submitted their tender responses on January 8, 2016 for the supply, installation and commissioning of the Digital Learning Solution for the 22,000 public primary schools.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The eight companies or consortium that were evaluated were: Kenyatta University & BRCK Ltd/Guangzhou Institute of Technology, Symphony Technologies Ltd and Multimedia University/Equity Holding Group/Tsinghua TongFang Co Ltd,   Hewlett – Packard EA Ltd and Dedan Kimathi University of Technology and Meru University of Science and Technology/Participatia Technologia", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Others were Jomo Kenyatta University of Agriculture and Technology and POSITIVO BGH, Moi University & JP SA Couto, S.A, Lenovo EA Limited, Trans Business Machine, Specicom and Ensure Services and the University Of Nairobi & Huawei Technologies Ltd", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "They were part of the 10 companies that had been issued with the RFP documents on November 27, 2015. The Expression of Interest proposals were opened on September 22, 2015 at the ICT Authority offices. In the opening, a total number of 25 companies or successfully submitted their proposals by the deadline.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The project is being implemented through a multi-agency approach that consists of the Ministry of Education, Science and Technology, Ministry of Industrialization and Enterprise Development, Ministry of Energy and Petroleum, The National Treasury and the Office of the Attorney General.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The ICT Authority is the lead implementing agency for the programme. Other agencies include The Teacher Service Commission, Kenya Institute of Curriculum Development, Rural Electrification Authority, Kenya Power, Kenya National Union of Teachers and Kenya Primary Schools Head Teachers Association.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "According to Phyllis Nyambura from the ICT Authority, the components have so far been delivered on schedule with the Interactive Digital Content for standard one pupils being launched on December 15, 2015 by Kenya Institute of Curriculum Development.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The content is available on a universal platform on link ", "type": "text"}, {"text": "http://kicdinteractivecontent.ac.ke.", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "link", "attrs": {"rel": null, "href": "http://kicdinteractivecontent.ac.ke.", "title": null, "target": null}}]}, {"text": " Additionally, the Ministry of Energy recently announced that they have almost completed connecting power to schools.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "A total of 66,000 teachers have been trained on digital literacy and are awaiting a refresher course in the next few weeks.", "type": "text"}]}], "article_image": "laptop-project-1727342001.jpg", "back_cta_link": "entry::3237", "article_excerpt": "The delayed promise for 983,271 laptops for Standard One pupils has moved a step closer to reality with the selection of local universities to supply the gadgets.", "blog_categories": ["trending"], "article_location": "Lorem Ipsum", "article_subtitle": null, "article_back_to_text": "Back to Blogs", "article_banner_image": "laptop-project.jpg", "enable_article_subtitle": null, "home_slider_banner_image": null, "enable_article_home_slider": false}

{"seo": [], "title": "A Wet Kisumu Rally Leaves the Title Race Wide Open", "years": ["2016"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q2"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Wed-05-2016", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "11th May, 2016", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "italic"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "In the Kenyan context at least, the weather forecasts were correct this past weekend. This was one of the wettest rallies we have had in recent years if you don’t count the KCB Kajiado rally late in 2015. Kisumu City was the host of the KNRC round 2, an event marred by weather challenges that saw three out of the five competitive stages cancelled.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "First we would like to wish legendary rally driver Ian Duncan a quick recovery. Ian was forced to retire even though he was leading after the first stage due to medical reasons. We wish him best of luck as he prepares for the Safari Rally slated for June 10-12.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "It took him a while. Last time he won in Kisumu was the year 1998. Baldev Chager navigated by Ravi Soni clinched the win with Rajbir Rai coming  a close second (14 seconds) and Manvir Baryan taking the last podium spot.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "History was again made in Kisumu. In the year 2015, the Kisumu rally saw the debut of the Ford Fiesta R5s in Kenya. Feisty tiny machines they are. This past weekend saw two Ford Fiestas on the podium for the first time ever. Rabjir & Manvir are certainly getting used to these machines and it’s only a matter of time before one of them wins a series or a championship.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "This was also a very good rally for the all ladies team of Natasha Tundo & Chantal Young, coming at an impressive 12", "type": "text"}, {"text": "th", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "superscript"}]}, {"text": " overall position. Tapio Laukkanen who was a huge favorite to win this weekend had punctures in both stages and could only manage a 14", "type": "text"}, {"text": "th", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "superscript"}]}, {"text": " overall position. {"seo": [], "title": "Nairobi’s Central Location Makes it a Hub for High Class Hotels in Africa", "years": ["2019"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q4"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Fri-12-2019", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Kenya is likely to sustain growing number of hotels in its capital even during low seasons.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Experts say the country is in a central position that enables top executives of multinational companies to access their businesses spread regionally.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“Normally when such things like travel advisories are issued it affects the high end visitors who like identifying with five star hotels but what we are seeing is an upsurge in the number of three to four star hotels coming in different parts of Nairobi,” says Estelle Verdier, the Jovago Managing Director.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“But the recent efforts by the government to encourage local tourism is likely to play a big role in driving business to the three and four star hotels coming up in the country,” she said in an interview.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "She says government’s efforts in upgrading most roads in the country and improving the Jomo Kenyatta International Airport will be a game changer in opening various parts of the country to visitors.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "A study released by W Hospitality Group, a member of Hotel Partners Africa shows that there are 40,000 hotel rooms planned for construction on the African continent between now and 2017 with 1,437 to be put up in Nairobi.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Villa Rosa Kempinski, established in 1897 as a luxury hotel group, opened doors to guests on September 1 with 200 hotel rooms along Chiromo road in Nairobi. The hotel has a portfolio of 74 five-star hotels in 32 countries and continues to add new properties in Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Asia.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "In May this year, Hemingways, a global hotel chain opened a Sh1.5 billion facility in Nairobi, targeting the growing luxury and travel business.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Marriot, another five star international hotel plans to open a hotel in Kenya by 2015 in a Sh127 billion ($1.5 billion) investment in Kenya, Ethiopia, Ghana, Benin, Gabon, Nigeria and Rwanda.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "New York Stock Exchange-listed Company Hilton Worldwide during last year announced it has signed a franchise agreement with Reliance Hotels to open Hilton Garden Inn hotel at the Jomo Kenyatta International Airport in Nairobi.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The hotel becomes the 12th Hilton Garden Inn property under development in Africa, and is expected to open in early this year.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The 171-room hotel will be located two kilometres from Jomo Kenyatta International Airport (JKIA), the country’s largest airport and a busy hub for sub-Saharan travel.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Accor, a global chain intends to open 30 new hotels with nearly 5,000 new rooms in Kenya, South Africa, Angola, Nigeria, Ghana, Morocco and Algeria by 2016. Emaar Hospitality Group, a Dubai based hotel group also has its eyes set on the East African region.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Other hotel brands seeking to invest or have invested in Kenya include Radisson Blu, Park Inn Lonrho hotels and Louvre Hotels Group founded by Mitsumi Group.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Located in Nairobi’s Westlands area, the Sh2.5 billion Louvre Hotels Group has 94 rooms and now boasts of seven hotels in the East African region, including Rwanda, Ethiopia and Tanzania.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Reacting to media questions on why Louvre Hotels Group decided to set up hotel in Kenya, Jagat Shah, Mitsumi Group chairman and Chief Executive Office says “The country is experiencing a lot of growth and development in the tourism sector and we felt that it was the right time for a world’s renowned hotel chain to set footprint in Kenya.”", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Kenya Tourism Board Acting chief executive officer Jacinta Mwatela calls on investors to exploit the hotel industry and fill up the huge gap particularly the economy category which has been ignored for a long time to boost domestic tourism.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“We need to diversify our mass markets while maintaining high standards that focus on customer satisfaction”, she added.  Ms Mwatela wants private sector in the hospitality industry to work closely with Kenya Tourism Board in creating an enabling environment that creates job opportunities for many young people across the country.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Louvres Hotel Group is now present in 8 sub-Saharan African countries, with 13 hotels comprising a total of 2,020 rooms under its Tulip Inn, Golden Tulip and Royal Tulip brands as it pursues more growth opportunities in the African region.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The country receives nearly two million visitors annually, but the bed capacity is still inadequate with industry players projecting that an additional 10,000–15,000 hotel rooms will be needed in the next five to 10 years to accommodate the expected rise in the number of tourists coming to Kenya.", "type": "text"}]}], "article_image": "class-hotels-in-africa-1727342350.jpg", "back_cta_link": "entry::3237", "article_excerpt": "Experts say the country is in a central position {"seo": [], "title": "Kenya’s New Shopping Malls Attract Global Supermarket Chains", "years": ["2016"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q2"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Mon-05-2016", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "23rd May, 2016", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "italic"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Kenyans are set to experience international shopping going by the interest from global supermarkets setting up in Nairobi’s new Malls.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "A research released by Knight and Frank say supermarkets from outside Africa are making an entry to Kenya’s retail market either through partnership with local businesses or direct in a move inspired by high levels of recent mall constructions.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The Kenyan market is currently dominated by Nakumatt, which has more than 20 supermarkets in Nairobi, while other major players include Tuskys, Naivas and Uchumi. “Retailers from outside of Africa are taking a growing interest in Kenya, and the most high profile imminent market entrant is the French supermarket chain Carrefour, which will be an anchor tenant at both Two Rivers and The Hub Malls,” says Knight and Frank.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“The Turkish fashion retailer LC Waikiki will also be entering the Kenyan market by opening a store at Two Rivers Mall,” it says.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "To signify the looming competition in Kenya’s retail market, the survey noted that a number of foreign retail chains are also considering setting up branches and are in the process of looking for partners to help them roll out.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "However the difficulty of sourcing appropriate local partners is regularly cited as a major obstacle to market entry by the interested chains.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“There are only a small number of local firms with the expertise to partner with international retailers, with the most prominent being Deacons, which operates brands such as Adidas, Mr Price and Bossini in Kenya,” says Knight and Frank.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "According to Knight and Frank research Nairobi has some of the finest shopping malls in Sub-Saharan Africa and many are in the pipeline of being developed which is making it more conducive for international retailers seeking to expand their footprint in the region to set up.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Nairobi is ranked as the largest market by existing shopping centre floor space and it has the biggest development pipeline. “Shopping centres have been a feature of Nairobi since the 1980s when the Sarit Centre, regarded as the city’s first formal mall, opened. Over the following decades, Nairobi’s retail landscape has been populated by other successful schemes such as Yaya Centre, Village Market and The Junction. However, the current wave of development is creating modern malls that are setting new standards for size and quality within the market.”", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The most prominent shopping centre opening in 2015 was the first phase of Garden City Mall, comprising 33,000 square meters. This is part of a large-scale mixed-use project developed by Actis, which also includes residential, office and hotel elements. It is planned to be fully completed in 2017, when the mall will be expanded to 50,000 square meters.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The development pipeline includes Centum’s keenly awaited Two Rivers project, which is expected to open in 2016. A 62,000 square meters mall will be delivered as part of the first phase of this major mixed-use scheme being built on a 100 acre site.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Another key project set to open in 2016 is The Hub in Karen, one of Nairobi’s wealthiest neighborhoods, which will offer 30,000 square meters of retail space and is being developed by Azalea Holdings, a consortium of local investors.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“Nairobi’s newest malls have leased well and the rents that they have achieved compare favorably with the city’s more established centres. Among the new projects, there is a clear trend towards mixed-use, rather than pure retail, development as office, residential and leisure facilities have been incorporated into schemes,” notes the survey.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Aside from Actis, most of the developers and landlords of Nairobi’s shopping centres are local Kenyan property owners. However, reflecting a trend seen elsewhere in Africa, there is growing interest in the market from South African investors, and Stanlib is understood to be poised to acquire Greenspan Mall in Donholm Estate.", "type": "text"}]}], "article_image": "new-shopping-malls-1727342500.jpg", "back_cta_link": "entry::3237", "article_excerpt": "Kenyans are set to experience international shopping going by the interest from global supermarkets setting up in Nairobi’s new Malls.", "blog_categories": ["business"], "article_location": "Lorem Ipsum", "article_subtitle": null, "article_back_to_text": "Back to Blogs", "article_banner_image": "new-shopping-malls.jpg", "enable_article_subtitle": null, "home_slider_banner_image": null, "enable_article_home_slider": false}

{"seo": [], "title": "Women in Isiolo Reaping Huge Returns from Camels", "years": ["2016"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q2"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Thu-06-2016", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "2nd Jun, 2016", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "italic"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "In the sweltering heat of Isiolo County, a group of women are locked up in a room trying to earn a decent living.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The women numbering 25 and largely drawn from Tawakal Group are engaged in camel milk business which is gaining popularity not only in Isiolo town but far counties such as Nairobi, Naivasha and Nakuru for its health benefits.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Once the sole preserve of nomadic Somali and Middle East communities, camel milk, which is naturally semi-skimmed, three times as rich in vitamin C as cows’ milk and packed with antibodies, is increasingly being recognized for its health benefits by health conscious consumers.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "In Nairobi, camel milk is now available in restaurants and supermarkets. For more adventurous foodies, camel milkshakes and camelcino (a cappuccino made with camel milk) can be found in some eateries.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "”We get our supply from herders, some keeping the animals in neighboring Samburu and Meru Counties. We preserve the commodity in the fridges before transporting them to the Nairobi market,” said the Chairlady of the group Dekha Adow.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "One of the group’s supplier is Adan Abdi who rides to Shab Hills along the Isiolo-Meru border, a distance of 50km to collect the milk on daily basis.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "”I wake up at 4.30 am every day to bring 100 litres of camel milk for the group. I make two trips and I am through with my work by 2 pm,” said Abdi.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The group also gets more supply from Mulango, 20 km west of Isiolo town and Archers Post in Samburu East.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "”This is low season. It’s difficult to get more than 300 litres as the camels are in lactating period,” explained Ms Adow.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "During the peak season, the women sell up to 3,000 litres of fresh milk to the Nairobi market.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "At their cooling centre within a building the group owns, they also run a milk bar where they sale fresh, fermented and yoghurt milk to local customers as low as Sh 30 per cup.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "”Each member has specific roles. Some work at the milk bar while others in the cold room. At night others take the milk to the stage where they are ferried to Nairobi by buses,” said the official.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "They buy a litre at Sh 80 from the farmers and sell at Sh 150 and Sh 200 of the same quantity in Isiolo town and Nairobi respectively.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "”We have an order from Eastleigh in Nairobi to supply them milk on daily basis. We get our money at the end of the month,” said Adow.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Their clients are mostly refugees from Somalia who live in Nairobi.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "”In Nairobi, the milk is sold in hotels and they also package them and sell in supermarkets,” she added.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "But the group will be faced with dilemma when the supply of the milk increases.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "”The population of our main customers (the Somalia refugees) is decreasing in Nairobi. A sizeable number have either moved out of the country or relocated to refugee camps,” said the group.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "At the milk bar, the operator, Maimuna Mohammed said the group sells a small glass of milk at Sh 30 and the big glass at Sh 80. The varieties are fresh, fermented and yoghurt of various flavors.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "”We sell an average of 100 litres of milk to consumers in Isiolo town every day,” said Ms Mohammed.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Sulekha Mohammed said the group started in 2013 and they benefited from training on hygiene and business management at the Naivasha Dairy Training Institute under a project funded through Swedish International Development Agency (Sida) and National Agriculture and Livestock Extension Policy (Nalep).", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "”Apart from the training, we also got donation of milk gallons of 500 kg and six fridges,” she said.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The group, three years into the business, has managed to buy a plot and construct a commercial building.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "”We operate from here and occupy two of the main front shops. We have rented the others,” said Mohammed.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Group members also own camels where it currently stands at 89 while they help each through merry-go round of Sh 25,000 for each member.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "”We use the money from merry-go round to meet our basic family needs,” said Mohammed.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The group has also ventured into selling camel meat called locally ‘nyirinyiri’ (meat cut into tiny pieces and deep-fried).", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "”Nyirinyiri is a Somali delicacy that is in high demand and if well-preserved can stay for up to a month,” stated the official.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "They send the prepared meat in metal containers to Nairobi twice a week where a kilogram fetches Sh 1,200. They take 160 kg per week. A kilogram of raw meat is sold in butcheries at Sh 400 in Isiolo town.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The women buy the meat from local butcheries and prepare the meal themselves.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "”We get orders, some for weddings from Nairobi and even Tanzania,” she said.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The all-Muslim group does not take loans from banks as their faith forbids business charging interests and they started their business through personal and family contribution.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Recently they developed a business proposal that they sent to USAID funded Resilience and Economic Growth in the Arid Lands—Accelerated Growth (Regal-AG) on camel meat value addition product (nyirinyiri).", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "According to Regal-AG fact sheet on business development grants for this financial year, Tawakal’s proposal is among five from Isiolo and Marsabit that are at initial negotiation stages. If it goes through, they stand to benefit from a grant of Sh 2.5 million.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "According to a study commissioned by SNV, a Dutch NGO, estimated 340 million litres of camel milk was produced commercially in 2007, valued at more than Sh 8billion at the farm level. This makes the sub-sector larger than cotton and comparable with coffee.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "At the international level, the FAO estimates that camel milk trading could be worth $10 billion if key improvements are made and proper marketing is done.
