{"seo": [], "title": "Facts Only...", "years": ["2018"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q1"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Thu-03-2018", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "1st Mar, 2018", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "italic"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Not knowing where to start, I’ll just dive right into it. I saw a Twitter ", "type": "text"}, {"text": "thread", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "link", "attrs": {"rel": null, "href": "https://www.facebook.com/campusbizKE/photos/pcb.1936582083257376/1936581303257454/?type=3&theater", "title": null, "target": null}}]}, {"text": " sometime last week and boy! Vitu zingine huwezi lia so imebidi tu umecheka.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "We all had our dreams and ambitions.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Shout out to everyone who vowed their first joboz would rack in Ksh50K. Wewe na those classmates who swore to changing schools every term one side!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Or how about those that turned down joboz coz they weren’t in line with what you studied in school? Lemme just tell you – unless you studied teaching, medicine or engineering, from what I’ve seen, unaeza uziwa insurance na a wood & metal work trainee ?", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Ama those that equated internships to ‘not knowing your worth’. Seriously, that came from a good place.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "We’ll give it to you straight. {"seo": [], "title": "Safeguarding Tomorrow’s Environment Today", "years": ["2018"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q2"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Fri-06-2018", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "22nd Jun, 2018", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "italic"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Environmental sanity now is a matter of global concern, particularly at a critical point when the World is grappling with the vagaries of climate change.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "East Africa economies are highly dependent on their natural resources base—more than 50 percent of the region’s GDP comes from agriculture, mining, forestry, and fishing.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Over the past year alone, severe water shortages brought upon by climate change in many parts of the region were just as unfortunately, counterbalanced with rampant flooding elsewhere. Meanwhile, domestic and industrial pollution, ongoing deforestation, soil erosion, desertification, and poaching have further depleted our resources. As a result, livelihoods of more people today than ever before are more likely to be threatened due to some unforeseen event resource depletion.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Every year, the UN Environment designates a day to refocus the attention of the world over on the pressing concerns that continue to pose grave danger to humanity and its sustainability.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "This year, World leaders converged in New Delhi, India on June 5 to mark the 2018 World Environment Day. As is the custom of every celebration, the day was earmarked with a universal theme and this year was no different. Motivated by the urge to rally national governments, industries, communities and individuals to explore other sustainable alternatives, the theme ", "type": "text"}, {"text": "“Beat Plastic Pollution", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "italic"}]}, {"text": "”", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "bold"}]}, {"text": " is a call to action to reduce the production and excessive use of single-use plastic pollution.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Kenya is no exception to the global discourses around sustainable environmental conservation and the green economy. The National Government, through the Ministry of Environment took the much needed step towards a cleaner environment in August 28 last year when it imposed a ban on the production, importation, distribution and usage of single-use carrier bags which are used in most industrial sectors for packaging of finished commodities and carrying consumables from retail outlets.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The ban progressively took effect as from September 2017, when consumers and manufacturers were faced with the harsh realities of absence of the plastic bags from the market and forced to look for eco-friendly alternatives such as sisal bags, clothing bags and canvas bags.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "For the general population, this came as a sigh of relief from the congestion and drainage blockages caused by the litter build-ups that had equally discolored the beautiful natural environs in major towns and cities. But for the enterprises that profited from the unregulated production, the ban was a loss for a source of income. And indeed, it was a form of inconvenience as citizens were accustomed to using these plastics in their daily lives.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Almost a year later, it would appear a lot still needs to be done to ensure full compliance with this law.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "A focus on recycling Plastic", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "bold"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The collection, management and disposal of waste continues to feature prominently as a challenge in our towns and cities. In many parts of the country, waste generation is a result of rapidly growing urban population and the changing patterns of consumption and industrialization. Thus, as consumer attitudes towards their responsibility to the planet changes the push for cleaner working and living environment is more crucial.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Social enterprises are leading the way in this front, concentrating and tackling waste management (plastic pollution), chronic youth unemployment, deforestation and climate change. Truly, this is commitment the national government and the devolved units are called to advocate and champion.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "In East Africa, our neighboring sister state Rwanda was the only country to have successfully implemented a total ban on plastic use before Kenya joined the bandwagon. The Kenyan national government attempted the ban three times prior to the official total ban in August 8", "type": "text"}, {"text": "th", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "superscript"}]}, {"text": " and with the ban came heavy penalties on defaulters. Therefore, this year’s environmental day is not only timely for the world but for Kenya specifically as the country marks 9 months since the policy was effected.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Plastic bottles and plastic bags are resistant to biodegradation and because of this the long term effects of pollution is far reaching. A recent study conducted by the UN Environment indicated that 2,000 tonnes of the 4,000 tons of plastic materials produced each month in Kenya end up in municipal waste streams and landfills. The Nairobi River is an example of the agonizing testimony to this truth.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "But that’s not where it ends. Public and private sector players, as well as individuals have to jointly address the issue of climate change. ", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "ESG Implementation", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "bold"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "As a bank, our focus is enhancing responsible banking practices through improving access to financial services while being a social and environmental lender. KCB Group introduced green financing as a core element of banking practices by embedding environment and social risk considerations into financial decisions.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Within the framework, the bank’s environmental and social management system seeks to assess and understand how clients and customers are managing environmental risks associated with projects they are running. The process is referred to as Environmental and Social Governance (ESG).", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "KCB Group has purposed to continue conducting due diligence of all its customers and corporate clients in order to ensure qualifying financing projects are in compliance with environmental standards. In addition, we have included the environmental and social risk governance for our clients who have also shared their journey towards internalization of sustainability into their business that has led to their growth.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Moving forward, KCB hopes to finance more clients in the green building, renewable energy and other infrastructure sectors, with an eye at safeguarding a sober environment.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "It is our belief that these efforts, combined with continuous improvement towards our goals, will raise our sustainability performance and help all of our stakeholders understand our intense desire for continued progress. We recognize the importance of our work for the future of our business and the communities we serve and we are ready to deliver on our promise to our stakeholders.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Embracing and blending environmental and social aspects of sustainability can enable organisations to drive stronger business performance into the future.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Keeping our environment clean is a collective effort and it is the responsibility of every Kenyan to ensure we safeguard tomorrow’s habitats today.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": " ", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "By: Joshua Oigara", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The writer is KCB Group CEO and MD", "type": "text"}]}], "article_image": "safeguarding-tomorrows-environment-1727702358.png", "back_cta_link": "entry::3237", "article_excerpt": "Environmental sanity now is a matter of global concern, particularly at a critical point when the World is grappling with the vagaries of climate change.", "blog_categories": ["trending"], "article_location": "Lorem Ipsum", "article_subtitle": null, "article_back_to_text": "Back to Blogs", "article_banner_image": "safeguarding-tomorrows-environment.png", "enable_article_subtitle": null, "home_slider_banner_image": null, "enable_article_home_slider": false}

Creating a budget plan will be your first step towards gaining control over your money and life in terms of building your wealth.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "To get a good budget in place, here are some items you need to look at:", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Your income:", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "bold"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The biggest wealth building tool today is your income. You should be aware of how many sources of income you have, and how much they generate. This enables you to understand your inflow and therefore dictates your expenditure.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Your Expenses:", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "bold"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Do you truly know how much you spend? Let’s face it, most of us have unplanned spending habits that often leave us scratching our heads-maybe this is how many go bald, or is it? Make a list of your regular expenses; bills such as rent, utilities, savings, and of course cash for an emergency kitty.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Remember to factor in how much you spend on entertainment and lunch, as well as shopping for clothes and other personal effects. Try and do your shopping in bulk to save by volume and shop as few times as possible to avoid the temptation of spending on unplanned items. Keep a small kitty for the fun activities such as hanging out with your friends, travel and days when you feel like giving yourself a treat.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Control your Payments:", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "bold"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Did you know that not many people factor in the cost of frequent money transfers? Whether it’s via mobile money, ATM withdrawals, card swipes, over the counter withdrawals, cheques issued, standing orders and more, each attracts a charge. It would be prudent to have a checking account that has the cheapest fees to operate, so each time you access your account you aren’t charged. While carrying cash or keeping it handy might be a security risk, it sometimes is cheaper to pay with since there aren’t extra fees to handle the transaction. Try and make as few withdrawals from the account as possible.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Plan for the Next Year:", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "bold"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "To achieve your goal, it is good to remember that your budget is a work in progress. Keep written notes so that you can be better prepared to tackle next year’s budget.", "type": "text"}]}], "article_image": "101-of-setting-a-budget-1727702994.jpg", "back_cta_link": "entry::3237", "article_excerpt": "Setting a budget can either be the hardest or the easiest thing you can ever do. {"seo": [], "title": "Credit score. How does it affect you?", "years": ["2016"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q1"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Thu-02-2016", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "11th Feb, 2016", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "italic"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Information about an individual’s finances and credit worthiness is one of the most sensitive categories of personal information. If you are applying for a loan, mortgage, credit card or any other form of borrowing you should check your credit report. If not, it’s still a good idea to check it from time to time just to make sure that you haven’t missed any payments without realizing it in case you are servicing a loan. You can check your credit report as often as you like and it won’t affect your credit rating or credit score.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "A good credit score means it will be easy for you to access loans in any institution despite the amount you are applying for. With today’s world becoming digitized, as an individual or a business owner, you can check your details via mobile text. We have Crystobol for example, which gives real time credit status based on payment history with banks, other financial institutions, suppliers of goods and services and utility companies reported to the credit bureau.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "One of the major factors that determines your credit score is how much revolving credit you have versus how much you’re actually using. The smaller that percentage is, the better it is for your credit rating. As a bank customer you can manage your account from the comfort of your home, office or even on the move through Internet and mobile Banking services. Online or mobile Banking service is designed to make your life much easier and let’s face it, convenience at this day and age is golden. As long as you have internet access, a smart phone or a tablet, you can complete numerous transactions without ever having to visit a branch.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Following the launch of IPRS (Integrated Population Registry System) in 2015, banks and other lending institutions are now able to determine or review your credit history. Credit score is the first thing the bank or a lending institution will determine before approving any loan that you apply for. Your landlord most probably also accessed this information before he approved you to be a tenant. A good credit score can get you a lower interest rate when you borrow which means you will pay less over time. So, in the end, it really pays to understand your credit scores and to make them as strong as possible.", "type": "text"}]}], "article_image": "credit-score-1727703151.jpg", "back_cta_link": "entry::3237", "article_excerpt": "Information about an individual’s finances and credit worthiness is one of the most sensitive categories of personal information.", "blog_categories": ["savings"], "article_location": "Lorem Ipsum", "article_subtitle": null, "article_back_to_text": "Back to Blogs", "article_banner_image": "credit-score.jpg", "enable_article_subtitle": null, "home_slider_banner_image": null, "enable_article_home_slider": false}

{"seo": [], "title": "Solutions to paying loans", "years": ["2016"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q1"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Mon-02-2016", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "15th Feb, 2016", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "italic"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Many would want to own a home, pay school fees for the children, drive a good car, take care of medical bills and sort out expenses and responsibilities that life throws at us without having to take up a loan.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The truth is, most of us got through university with the aid of student loans that most of us are still servicing.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The fact remains that loans are an important and convenient part of our lives. This is where some people get stuck between a rock and a hard place-having taken a loan with no idea on how to go about repaying it.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Many people have ended up being auctioned or sued in court over unpaid loans. You would be the class clown for the month with every opportunity exploited to make reference to you ‘action-packed’ holiday.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The struggle was indeed real at that time.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "With the turn of the millennium, climate change and tough economic times have led the society to quickly change this notion. Yes, we dare say, Agriculture is sexy!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Technology has revolutionized literally every aspect of our life and Agriculture hasn’t been left behind. The current trend indicates that this figure will double by 2045, according to the 2012 African Economic Outlook report.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The Kenya National Bureau of Statistics does not have statistics on unemployment rates. However, various publications have inferred that unemployment and underemployment in the country stand at between 25 and 40%. According to a trend analysis done by UNDP (Kenya’s Youth Employment Challenge, 2013), the age range of 18 to 25 represents the years that unemployment is highest. This has been viewed as a demographic dividend for Africa, will it just happen or we must do something to earn this dividend?", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "As redundancies and retrenchments become the order of the day, more and more pundits are touting entrepreneurship as the key to enhancing job creation and a sustainable future. From the statistics on small businesses, only 5% make it to their 5th year.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Success rates are significantly predicated on capital access, product-market fit, and management expertise in key areas.  This is why KCB has come in calling with the Lions den, which ended its season 1 last year. KCB Lions’ Den, Kenya’s biggest business reality television show is back soon and around 72 entrepreneurs have a chance to either go home with what they have been looking for the most of go walk away hopeless to contribute to the many business ideas that haven’t attracted enough capital to see the light of day.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The KCB Lions’ Den television show allows entrepreneurs all over Kenya a chance to pitch their business to a panel of five of the country’s most dynamic and adventurous investment leaders. So what does it take to walk home with that coveted cheque? Every other day I advise guys who have or think they have great business ideas on how to attract investor funds. I believe that there is no clearly articulated great business idea that doesn’t have money around it. I have done consultancies for organisations that have so much funds streaming to them not mainly because they have great business ideas but whatever the idea, they articulated it clearly, concisely and in a compelling manner. These are the cardinal values of an elevator pitch.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "These can be delivered through the following seven steps of preparing an elevator pitch. {"seo": [], "title": "How to Recover Financially After Overspending During the Holidays", "years": ["2018"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q1"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Wed-02-2018", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "7th Feb, 2018", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "italic"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The holidays are over, the children are back in school and you are back in the office!  Lots of things have changed, like your waistline… but the most important thing, is the size of your wallet. While it was fat and flowing to family, friends and relatives during the holidays; this Njaanuary has taught you, yet again, that you need to learn to control your overspending during the holidays. In order to get out of the woods, you need to both recover the money overspent, and save for the year as well and this is how you should do it:", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "orderedList", "attrs": {"start": 1}, "content": [{"type": "listItem", "content": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Develop a plan", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "bold"}]}]}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Prior to taking any financial action this year, it is important that you have already developed a strategy to get out of debt without forcing you to dip into emergency savings or borrowing money.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "orderedList", "attrs": {"start": 2}, "content": [{"type": "listItem", "content": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Pay off extra when possible", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "bold"}]}]}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "It is never a good idea to ignore your debt as your bills are not going to disappear, and, moreover, you will ruin your credit rating. Do not let your bills get out of control and always ensure you cover at least the minimum payment.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "orderedList", "attrs": {"start": 3}, "content": [{"type": "listItem", "content": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Consolidate your debts", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "bold"}]}]}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "This process of debt-refinancing involves taking out one loan to pay off many others, specifically if you racked up a high amount of consumer debt. With a ", "type": "text"}, {"text": "KCB M-PESA Loan", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "link", "attrs": {"rel": null, "href": "https://ke.kcbgroup.com/home/loans/mobile/kcb-m-pesa", "title": null, "target": null}}, {"type": "bold"}]}, {"text": ", you can borrow between Ksh 50-1, 000, 000 as well as choose to repay within 1, 2 or 6 months.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "orderedList", "attrs": {"start": 4}, "content": [{"type": "listItem", "content": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Using the 50/50 trick", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "bold"}]}]}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "If you tend to spend a lot and save almost nothing, you should try this convenient trick. It is especially useful whenever you make a purchase that is not necessary, for example, a new pair of earphones. With this trick, you put the same amount of what you spent on your purchase into your savings account. This is a great method of holding yourself accountable for your financial activities, as well as a way to build your savings.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "orderedList", "attrs": {"start": 5}, "content": [{"type": "listItem", "content": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Cash method", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "bold"}]}]}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Shopping with plastic increases your likelihood of spending more money than when shopping with cash, as evidenced by numerous studies. This is because you cannot see the money literally going away like you do when swiping. In addition, avoid online shopping while undergoing financial recovery, we know it’s therapy but trust us it’ll all pay off.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The holidays may be over, but the stain of overspending is not so easily washed off… If you are asserting that 2018 is your year, then you need to take action and ensure you recover financially.", "type": "text"}]}], "article_image": "2017-resolutions-1727774013.jpg", "back_cta_link": "entry::3237", "article_excerpt": "The holidays are over, the children are back in school and you are back in the office!  Lots of things have changed, like your waistline…", "blog_categories": ["trending"], "article_location": "Lorem Ipsum", "article_subtitle": null, "article_back_to_text": "Back to Blogs", "article_banner_image": "2017-resolutions-1727774009.jpg", "enable_article_subtitle": null, "home_slider_banner_image": null, "enable_article_home_slider": false}

{"seo": [], "title": "Banking on Diaspora Remittances To Boost Growth", "years": ["2018"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q2"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Sat-06-2018", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "30th Jun, 2018", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "italic"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Various stories abound of Kenyans in the Diaspora who made elaborate plans to invest back home, and, trusting in relatives or friends to get the job done, ended up ruing the day they made that decision.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Kenyans have powerful cultural ties that they never seem to give up. We love our families and extended families such that even while working in other parts of the world, we always keep an eye on what is happening back home.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The statistics bear us out.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Data released by the Central Bank of Kenya (CBK) showed that diaspora remittances reached $222.55 million (Ksh 22.25 billion) in March 2018, a growth of 51% per cent compared to $147.52 million (Sh14.75 billion) the same month last year.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Information from the report shows that remittances as a share of GDP stabilized at 2.3 per cent over the 12 months to March 2018, underlying the fact that Diaspora remittances have become a key support of the shilling which is under pressure due to low export earnings.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "It is important to recognize that the diaspora community is a major enabler towards economic growth and a critical driver towards the achievement of our overarching vision of an economically sound East African community.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The East Africa region receives about $ 3.5 Billion annually. This is a big contribution which we believe will continue growing substantially in the coming years on the back of continued investments by the government and institutions like us to facilitate the Diaspora communities. In Kenya, remittances account for 4% of GDP.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Over the past few decades, the Diaspora population has become more prominent on the world stage. This puts it at a very unique position to contribute to boosting the economic growth and prosperity of our country. With our growing consumer markets, the consciousness of return and the synergies for growth, dignity and freedom, we are poised to enter into the league of the Asian Tigers.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": " ", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Kenya is working to ensuring that Kenyans in diaspora can efficiently invest back at home. A few years ago, the government launched a Diaspora Policy that guides us in harnessing the wealth and expertise of Kenyans in the diaspora to our development efforts. The policy is pegged on five pillars – economic diplomacy, peace diplomacy, environmental diplomacy, cultural diplomacy and Diaspora diplomacy. The core of the economic diplomacy pillar is the search for a robust and sustained economic growth as envisaged by Vision 2030.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "With the booming real estate industry, this is usually the first point of call considering the opportunity that comes with the surge in urban development and population growth. Funding from the diaspora has spurred rapid growth in the real estate sector, making it one of the fastest growing sectors according to the latest Economic Survey from the government.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The rising remittances have provided a useful source of foreign exchange for the country, helping raise reserves as well as maintaining the stability of the shilling.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Research has found that increasing remittances lead to reduced poverty, enhance human and economic development since it provides income for households, education, health care, housing, small businesses and farming. Recipients of these remittances tend to put more money into these sectors than those who do not receive any.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Additionally, technological advances have made remittance transactions faster, cheaper and more convenient, making it possible to reach even the “last mile” of many remote areas.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "As people continue to cross borders seeking better opportunities for themselves and their families, financial investments back home have been made easier by improved communication technologies.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The infrastructural development such as the Standard Gauge Railway play a significant role in alleviating poverty in their domicile countries and beyond. It also offers a chance for individuals to become an integral part of transforming Africa.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Our economy flourishes from billions of shillings remitted each year by Kenyans either working or studying abroad owing to Kenyans’ enhancing their connection with what happens on the ground back home.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "To leverage the impact of remittances for both the individual families and their communities while curbing skepticism that may limit their prospects in making investments back home, the banking industry is providing solutions that facilitate secure and profitable investments effortlessly with guidance from experts.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "There are mortgage propositions for example that cover access to property developers and agents by linking interested home owners with vetted property developers and agents to ensure that the journey to home ownership is stress-free. Additionally, there are multi-currency home loans with added value in the form of project management of construction projects at reasonable costs.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Spurring development in the country is a prerogative of all Kenyans and this is being enabled by expanding access to the financial system, thereby providing recipients with more options to save, invest, and use their remittances productively.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Indeed, the realization has now hit that diaspora remittances can have transformative effects on their livelihoods and communities, with well-invested funds stimulating employment and income generating opportunities.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Partnerships hold the key to realizing the growing scale and potential impact of diaspora remittances by reducing costs and saving time while creating a gateway to financial inclusion.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": " ", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": " By: Annastacia Kerich  Kimtai,", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": " KCB Group, Retail Director", "type": "text"}]}], "article_image": "default-news-1727774222.jpeg", "back_cta_link": "entry::3237", "article_excerpt": "Various stories {"seo": [], "title": "Banking on the Youth to Spur Agriculture", "years": ["2018"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q3"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Tue-09-2018", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "4th Sep, 2018", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "italic"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": " Africa is a youthful continent, with over 60 percent of the population below the age of 30 years.  At over 300 million, the population of the youth continue to rise.  The current trend indicates that this figure will double by 2050.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Despite the large youthful population, the continent has failed to use this potent resource to grow economies and unemployment, underemployment and limited economic opportunities pose the biggest hindrances to our youth.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Across the continent, youth, including university graduates, have had to resort to menial jobs and sometimes end up in a life of crime because of the lack of employment or investment opportunities. The opportunities are even rarer in rural areas where agriculture is the mainstay of the communities.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "A combination of poor yields, low profitability and manual methods make farming unattractive, and the youth are increasingly drawn to urban areas. The inevitable consequence of this rural-urban migration is the decline of agriculture. This is an unacceptable reality for a continent with such an impressive pool of youth.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Despite these challenges, there is a sliver of good news. Africa’s growing youth population comes with high energy, creativity and talents, which could be channeled into an economic boom. The youth present an opportunity that can be harnessed to ensure sustainable food security and food production.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "As Kenya joins the world in marking the International Youth Day on August 12, there is a greater need to highlight the benefits of agriculture as a career for young people. In particular, these are opportunities for greater market engagement, innovation and farming as a business. There is need for concerted efforts between the private sector, government and development actors to support youth-centric programmes so as to realise this. All players need to step up the quest for creating more opportunities for self-employment for our youth.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The agriculture sector does not only have the latent possibilities to address the enormous economic problems being experienced across the continent; it would also serve as a driver of employment, mainly among the large vulnerable youth population, while ensuring enough food to feed the bulging population.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "As a country, Kenya can leverage on the dynamism of the youth to spur this sector to solve the twin challenge of unemployment and food insecurity. There are huge opportunities for job creation in the agricultural sector and along the agribusiness value chain. This however calls for innovation and concerted efforts from the government and the private sector to transform farming into an exciting and profitable venture.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "If we are to enable the youth to transform agriculture, then the barriers to engagement in the sector need to be addressed. For many of the youth, the challenge has always been access to finance, unavailability of land and technology.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "With the government making food security one of its Big Four priority areas for the next five years, the agriculture sector holds tremendous promise for catalysing growth and creating employment opportunities for the youth. The importance of the agricultural sector as an employer is likely to grow with continued transformation of food systems and growth in domestic demand for food.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "To bridge to the unemployment gap that exists among the youth, KCB Foundation launched the ", "type": "text"}, {"text": "2jiajiri ", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "italic"}]}, {"text": "Programme in 2016. Through this enterprise development programme the Bank seeks to empower and equip unemployed and out-of-school youth with technical skill training opportunities as well as up-skilling in various informal trades including agribusiness.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Through the innovative hydroponics farming technology, a soil-less farming method, and a subset of hydroculture, where plants are grown using only a mineral nutrient solution in a water solvent and mature within two to three months, the Bank seeks to grow youth in agribusiness; and bring them to a place where they can set up sustainable business enterprises and employ their peers, hence creating more  job opportunities.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "To scale the programme, KCB Foundation is partnering with County Governments and leveraging on their networks to reach out to the youth especially those upcountry. At the launch of the Kenya National Youth Week on 6", "type": "text"}, {"text": "th", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "superscript"}]}, {"text": " August KCB Foundation, the German Development Cooperation through GIZ and the Government of Makueni County have rolled out a new food and nutrition security programme that will see 150 youth engaged in agribusiness. The partnership, through its ", "type": "text"}, {"text": "2jiajiri ", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "italic"}]}, {"text": "programme, will sponsor the youth aged 18 to 35 years under the Makueni Youth Empowerment Service (M-YES) for a 3-month training on hydroponics farming.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Upon completion of the training, the beneficiaries will undergo business incubation services offered by KCB Foundation. They will be supported to develop business plans and access discounted financing to construct greenhouses on land sub-leased from the Government of Makueni County.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "As we celebrate the youth, we need to reevaluate how to handle the teeming youth population to yield economic dividends.  It should be our collective responsibility to support our youth to grow further to enable them feed the nation.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "By: Jane Mwangi", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "KCB Foundation Executive Director", "type": "text"}]}], "article_image": "agriculture-1727774336.jpg", "back_cta_link": "entry::3237", "article_excerpt": "Africa is a youthful continent, with over 60 percent of the population below the age of 30 years.  At over 300 million, the population of the youth continue to rise.  The current trend indicates that this figure will double by 2050", "blog_categories": ["trending"], "article_location": "Lorem Ipsum", "article_subtitle": null, "article_back_to_text": "Back to Blogs", "article_banner_image": "agriculture-1727774331.jpg", "enable_article_subtitle": null, "home_slider_banner_image": null, "enable_article_home_slider": false}

{"seo": [], "title": "Mobile Loan Safety Awareness", "years": ["2019"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q4"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Fri-12-2019", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "13th Dec, 2019", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "italic"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "I was walking to work today in a rather happy good-vibes-love-and-light kinda mood alafu nikao huyu mtu anawikanga siku nzima pale Archives. He’s not done anything to me (yet), but he took me back to a time in my life when… let’s just say it was possibly the lowest I’ve ever hit. I was young (by the way mi husound kama nikona miaka ngapi?)", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "If you frequent this blog a lot, then you’ve heard me postpone the story of my first salo. Today, I’m telling it. And Im telling it with my chest! And if you have anything to say about it, mnikujie Kencom.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Anyway, so I was an intern in a place I won’t mention because huwezi jua. The year was 2014. I was fresh out of campo. I did that ujanja of extending your internship hoping they’d see your loyalty and decide to keep you. (I still left that place an intern. I made plans and the universe laughed – and oouh, it laughed hard!).", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "During my academic internship, I wasn’t paid. But I had exposure (pffahaha! See what I did there?). They’d feed me – three meals like a rich kid! And they’d also sort my transport. What was a salary for, right? But after I graduated, vitu kwa ground zikachange. I was put on payroll and let me just say, thao sita kwa mtoto hajawai pata salo, whew!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Shida ni, us of small small monies tulikuwa tunalipwa in cash. My salo was handled like petty cash but I was rich! I will never forget how that envelope looked. And the way those notes stacked up in there. I had never seen anything so beautiful.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "I boarded my mat hapo Ngong Road and headed to town so I could take a jav home to the destination that is Rongai. Quite the journey. If you’ve ever been to Railways during rush hour then you are familiar with the untold madness that takes centre stage. The type-do rugby of watuz scrambling for sitting space and all. They say shetani akikuja anakujanga na wajukuu wote.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "As I waited, one of those watu wa kuwika came through. That thing about an idle mind being the devil’s playround? Believe it. Small I found myself in the crowd surrounding the mans. And it really does seem to me like wanajuanga wageni. It was me. I was the targeted mgeni.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "So this guy asked if anyone wanted their money doubled. We will never understand what came over me. I found myself volunteering so I could take home 12K. This story pains me. Nitarudi kumalizia. But the long-short of of it: that was the last I saw of my first salo.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "So now I ask, how do you guys get duped by those Kamiti texts talmbou’ “1%/0% interest rate on KB M-PESA loans”? Sielewi.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "2020, we do better.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Still, we move regardless.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Nimeenda kulia.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Send tissue.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Over&Out,", "type": "text"}, {"type": "hardBreak"}, {"text": "The Witty (teary, today) Banker.", "type": "text"}]}], "article_image": "loan-plug-that-saved-the-day-1727774468.jpg", "back_cta_link": "entry::3237", "article_excerpt": "I was walking to work today in a rather happy good-vibes-love-and-light kinda mood alafu nikao huyu mtu anawikanga siku nzima pale Archives.", "blog_categories": ["trending"], "article_location": "Lorem Ipsum", "article_subtitle": null, "article_back_to_text": "Back to Blogs", "article_banner_image": "loan-plug-that-saved-the-day-1727774458.jpg", "enable_article_subtitle": null, "home_slider_banner_image": null, "enable_article_home_slider": false}

{"seo": [], "title": "Back-to-Home Shenanigans", "years": ["2019"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q3"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Tue-08-2019", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "It’s that time again! Plezdents wamerudi kututawala. In many households, the effects of this auspicious event are being felt.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Mornings are noisy. Wallets a blowing dry with each note folks have to spend. Houses are full to the brim. One loaf of bread is no longer enough. You’re probably anxious and no, don’t feel guilty for wanting to send them to shaggz because whew! These are trying times when everything feels like an extreme sport.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "This takes me back to my days as the plezdent. My parents really got the blow of it all. Every holiday had one of us celebrating our birthdays and it was all the rage. So while your folks budgeted for a stay or some upcountry travel, mine had to do all that and plan to host the entire neighbourhood for our birthdays every holiday. Couple all that with Easter travels, Christmas, New Years, WHEW! Now it all makes sense when Mama Kingstone asks kina Kingstone ‘mnapereka wapi korogate?!’", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Kuna time fulani we were all home and it was my kid bro’s birthdays. There was the parties that were thrown for me and my big bro; and then there was THE birthday party that was thrown for the ‘baby of the house’. The difference was clearly evident and this time it was no different.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "My mom even had a birthday committee because ‘the baby must be spoilt rotten’. Plus wamama wa PTA na ploti had to know who’s who in the neighbourhood. After a couple of committee meetups, it was the big day. We will never make sense of who chose ‘ule Auintie wa kipackiwa chapo after events’ to be the treasurer but here we were.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "My auntie is a peculiar character. If you’ve read my past blogs you have probably brushed shoulders with my relaz ratchetry. Kuchoma ndio tulipenda. But what d’you do? You’ve gotta love the fam.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "She went missing in action and not only was she in charge of paying suppliers and caterers. The cake was also nowhere to be seen. My bro’s street cred legit stemmed from those things.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "As my mom and bro grew anxious, my unruly uncle mwenye huchoma family events zote came up with a bright idea. In his true form, he got onto the table and, in between hiccups, announced to the guests that my bro’s birthday had been postponed. You can do anything you put your mind to, even postponing birthdays.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Mom had to start from scratch when the new date was settled upon. Just had me wondering, kwani hizo siku there were no debit cards? Hii aibu yote would have been avoided if there wasn’t so much trust placed on my autie’s matress banking.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "This idea of not trusting banks has seen my relaz choma, tis was neither the first or last of it. Can never be me though. I was peeping KCBae’s debit card benefits and I just oop at anyone who wouldn’t go for it. I’m talking to you mom, don’t scroll.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Being able to pay for stuff at no extra cost? Ability to pay at millions of outlets? Bagging loyalty points for usage? Guaranteed security so my auntie doesn’t pull a Houdini with your loot? Ability to withdraw at any VISA branded ATM? Mkona jokes sana. And to top it all off, maneno yako inabaki between you and your bank.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "To this date, some rude neighbours still refer to us as the family that postpones birthdays. My auntie was next seen some two years down the line. She runs a successful birthday event organizing gig – the nerve!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "My heart goes out to you who’s going through the back-to-home trauma. You are not a bad parent for wanting to send them to shaggz. Mmeona unga ni pesa ngapi?", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "As a side note, sister ya Kingstone anaitwa nani?", "type": "text"}]}], "article_image": "home-shenanigans-1727781372.jpg", "back_cta_link": "entry::3237", "article_excerpt": "It’s that time again! Plezdents wamerudi kututawala. In many households, the effects of this auspicious event are being felt.", "blog_categories": ["trending"], "article_location": "Lorem Ipsum", "article_subtitle": null, "article_back_to_text": "Back to Blogs", "article_banner_image": "home-shenanigans-1727781365.jpg", "enable_article_subtitle": null, "home_slider_banner_image": null, "enable_article_home_slider": false}

{"seo": [], "title": "A Weekend of Champions", "years": ["2019"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q3"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Thu-07-2019", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Sometimes unakumbuka siku za kusema ‘Walapa’ na ‘Walapangaz’ and can’t help but think the slang these days just evolves in a very random way, but I digress", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Sometimes unakumbuka siku za kusema ‘Walapa’ na ‘Walapangaz’ and can’t help but think the slang these days just evolves in a very random way, but I digress. Anyway, I’m back and I’m better, with more juicy vibes on what went down this past weekend. Those who love sports (like Sospeter and I) were spoilt for choice. From Autocross to Rugby, Volleyball to Chess, tulirepresent – it was a Super Sunday!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The KCB Autocross was back and judging from the experience I had last time, I had to make an appearance huko Naks. The Autocross is sort of like Rally except for the fact that it allows the petrol-heads and speed junkies to partake in car shenanigans (By car shenanigans I mean, races, food, drinks, music and all round good vibes) It was epic my guy- there were people swarming in and out of the park, excited about the races. Na wacha nisianze story, there was lots of yummy food on-ground (nilishiba wasee), DJ alikua juu – as in… you had to be  there to experience the awesomeness.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Sospeter naye alienda Kakamega kusupport the boys, Rugby 7s things. (BTW alichukua leave ya Friday, akisema he’s gone for a wedding, kidogo kidogo we’re seeing him in pics with the guys lifting the trophy – Wakenya! – SMH). Anyway, we broke the so called jinx – to lift the inaugural Kakamega 7s series on Sunday evening, edging out Homeboyz 21-12 in a thrilling showdown. Naskia the celebration was serious – probably why Sospeter hajarudi job bado. The boys are back at it this weekend – as all roads lead to Meru for the Kabeberi 7s.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Watu wa chess pia hawakuachwa nyuma, huku Nairobi the KCB chess team edged out Equity Bank 3.5-1.5  to extend their lead at the Chess Kenya standings with 54 points. Sijui what exactly this means (hehe), but najua we’re ahead. BTW once of these days I need to start attending those games, siwezi toka hii bank nikijua kucheza tu draughts and we’ve have a quality Chess team.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Last but not least, Volleyball. This is where I shine – back in form three I used to be a champion. I remember the time I led the team to victory, even with a sprained wrist. I got said injury slashing grass of all things – nilikua nimetokea kwa list ya noisemakers (BTW why were noise makers even a thing? How were we supposed to communicate with one another….) the week before the finals. But this isn’t about me, it’s about the KCB ladies emergering victorious, after winning five consecutive games with margins of 3-0, they also thumped Kenya Pipeline 3-0.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Anyway, I think hii weekend nitakua tu indoors – but mtu akiamua kunitolea form, pia siwezi mind.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Over & Out", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The Witty Banker", "type": "text"}]}], "article_image": "a-weekend-of-champions-1727781575.jpg", "back_cta_link": "entry::3237", "article_excerpt": "Sometimes unakumbuka siku za kusema ‘Walapa’ na ‘Walapangaz’ and can’t help but think the slang these days just evolves in a very random way, but I digress", "blog_categories": ["sports"], "article_location": "Lorem Ipsum", "article_subtitle": null, "article_back_to_text": "Back to Blogs", "article_banner_image": "a-weekend-of-champions.jpg", "enable_article_subtitle": null, "home_slider_banner_image": null, "enable_article_home_slider": false}

{"seo": [], "title": "The KCB WRC Rally Returns", "years": ["2019"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q3"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Tue-07-2019", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Let’s take it back to way back when tulikwa tunavaa oversized red/blue slippers (or a mix of both) tukivuruga vumbi as we ran to spectate the Safari Rally? When life was easy and your biggest worry was where to get your Patco and where Boi took your brand new banoz.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Let’s take it back to way back when tulikwa tunavaa oversized red/blue slippers (or a mix of both) tukivuruga vumbi as we ran to spectate the Safari Rally? When life was easy and your biggest worry was where to get your Patco and where Boi took your brand new banoz.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "You know? Those days za kunyonya chipo mwitu from the corner of those pinkish creamish tuplastic bags? The days of buying ‘ice’ for a shilling and you end up looking like a smurf. The worst experiences zilikuwa kugongwa na ball ya foota then everyone laughs. Heaven must defo look and feel like childhood!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The excitement was undeniable; the energy? Infectious. We’d scream our little selves hoarse. Unbothered by the looming flus that awaited us the next day. It was one of the very times mom didn’t mind ukirudi home ukifanana na mat za Ruai. Everyone would come out to cheer. We were one big happy family.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "We’d often nudge each other to scream, ‘Hiyo gari ya yellow ni yangu!’ Good times those. I’m getting all teary just remembering it all. As the years went, the Safari Rally seemed to be progressively more and more scarce. And then, lights off…Ok, I’m being a bit dramatic. Allow it ??", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "And so we moved on with life and now ‘blooband’ generation wanaskianga tu that there was once an unbridled happiness whenever Safari Rally came to town.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Fast forward to present day 2019 and guess what? The #WRCSafariRally makes a come back to Kenya and whew! We were not ready! Set to cover about 797KMs across Nairobi, the Vasha and Kiambu counties, the legendary event that grew as all flights this weekend!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Today’s post is a little emo. I simply cannot imagine missing a taste of that childhood we miss so much. I’m excited. I’m anxious but more importantly, I haven’t felt this happy in the longest time. I haven’t eagerly awaited something this much. (Ok, I’m lying. Before Karen Masters I was even practicing how I was gonna say hi to Heavy K! And I did. Semeni “Ng’we” niangushe selfie.)", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Ok. I digress. My point is, this rally was special. It was different as it had a whole lot riding on it and I just cannot even put in words the magnitude!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "It was the perfect chance to connect with your childhood. If you could have a moment to relive it, I’m 100% you would. Life in this city is hard enough. Kwanza after they banned nduthi’s from the CBD nilikulanga to stress kila siku trekking from Ngara to Kencom – whew!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "This rally was also our chance to get back into the WRC which is a big deal in putting Kenya on the global motorsport map! If that doesn’t shake your boots, you suffer an acute lack of uzalendo.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Special prize for whoever spots me at the spectator stage for the next rally. I’ll be dropping the tea and deets for when and where that’ll be.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Let’s ride!", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Over & Out,", "type": "text"}, {"type": "hardBreak"}, {"text": "The Witty Banker.", "type": "text"}]}], "article_image": "wrc-rally-1727781740.jpg", "back_cta_link": "entry::3237", "article_excerpt": "Let’s take it back to way back when tulikwa tunavaa oversized red/blue slippers (or a mix of both) tukivuruga vumbi as we ran to spectate the Safari Rally?", "blog_categories": ["trending"], "article_location": "Lorem Ipsum", "article_subtitle": null, "article_back_to_text": "Back to Blogs", "article_banner_image": "wrc-rally.jpg", "enable_article_subtitle": null, "home_slider_banner_image": null, "enable_article_home_slider": false}

{"seo": [], "title": "Guru’ Narendra Raval, Man of Steel", "years": ["2019"], "cta_icon": null, "cta_link": null, "cta_text": null, "quarters": ["q2"], "categories": ["blogs"], "enable_cta": true, "updated_by": 30, "article_date": "Wed-06-2019", "article_text": [{"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "A large TV screen welcomes you to the head office of the largest steel factory in the region.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "A large TV screen welcomes you to the head office of the largest steel factory in the region. On the screen is a looping documentary on the journey the company has taken to become the behemoth it is today. Donning the walls are pictures of the Chairman, Narendra Raval in various poses with Very Very Important People. There is one with former President Daniel arap Moi. There is another with Narendra Modi, India’s Premier who, during a recent state visit to Kenya, squeezed some time to visit his old friend Raval, or Guru as he prefers being referred to, in his house in Nyari estate. The other is that of Raval with Mwai Kibaki, Kenya’s immediate past President. The most telling picture however is that of Guru adjusting Uhuru Kenyatta’s tie right where Raval’s cement and steel companies thrive. “The President is my friend and we have known each other for a long time,” says Raval as he ambles around his massive office. And it is a very big office. ", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The entire top floor of the office complex is a case study in good taste; ambient lighting covers the entire floor; the furniture is what you find in those expensive catalogues while the walls are decorated with art and rather pricey looking wallpaper. The floor is bedecked with the most expensive Italian marble, a turquoise blue there, a gray and blue tile thither. Yet, he wasn’t born with a silver spoon. “I started off at Gikomba in the cheapest store we could get because nobody was interested in the area as it was considered a very unsafe place,” says the former priest. Having seen a gap in the hardware business, he took a plunge by sinking his savings in buying and reselling steel. The Kshs 3,500 shillings a month in rent for 5,000 square feet was considered steep for the time and place but Raval was undeterred. It was a tough time for him and the country in general. During the late eighties and early nineties, Kenya was going through the labour pains of the advent of multi-partyism and the epicenter was usually the area around Gikomba. “I started off at Gikomba in the cheapest store we could get because nobody was interested in the area as it was considered a very unsafe place,”", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Stepping into the spacious reception of Devki Group of companies in the dusty little town of Ruiru, one is met by an antiseptic environment and tranquility that belies the reality outside the offices.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": " “All the riots were starting around where our shop was, on Kombo Munyiri road. We endured a lot of tear gas”, says Raval rather mistfully. He started off buying steel from the existing mills and within five years, his store had become the largest steel hardware shop in the area. Having sold steel and seen the margins manufacturers were making, Raval decided to backward integrate by venturing into manufacturing. At the time, there were only a couple of steel rolling mills in the country that basically had a tight hold on the market. Raval found a site in Athi River, 30 kilometres from the city centre, where he planned to make his dream a reality. “We bought 25 acres at Sh35,000 an acre. At the time, the whole place was nothing but a thick bush. Only Kenya Meat Commission had established in the area,” he says. Having bought the land, Raval was left penniless. He did not even have enough money to put up a boundary wall. “I used a have a pick up Toyota KXU 905 (today I don’t remember the number plates of any of my cars but this one I remember which means whoever stays with you in difficult times you will never forget them) that I used to ferry stones from the quarry for building the wall”, he says.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "After the fencing project, Raval approached KCB Bank for financing to set up his steel rolling mill. He had never done a business plan before, but he gave it a shot. It was shy of the bank’s expectations and as a result, he hired an expert who helped him prepare a proper plan. A KCB Bank manager, whom ", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The number of employees employed directly by the Devki Group. Thousands more are employed indirectly. 4,000.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "“It was very nice of KCB Bank what they did to me. That’s why till today, I tell my board of directors that we will not ever leave KCB Bank because they understand the Kenyan market, they understand the people, and the business way of Kenya. “ ", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "BRANCHING OUT", "type": "text", "marks": [{"type": "bold"}]}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "He fondly remembers as Mr. Ndambuki, kept encouraging him during the loan application process. Finally, he applied and received US$100,000 (at the time equivalent to Sh36 million) which he used to purchase his first steel rolling equipment. Production would start after KCB Bank gave him a letter of credit to import the raw materials needed to kick off the business. But a setback was to strike immediately he started production.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The global price of steel not only crashed spectacularly, but a couple  of local competitors, keen on running Devki out of business, ganged up by undercutting him on the price. Raval’s steel was piling up in the godown and the market was flooded. “For five months, I could not pay salaries for my employees but they stuck by me. It was very nice of my bank and the Kenyan workers, some of whom are still working with me, to stick by the company,” says Raval. ", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "To his relief, KCB Bank did not push him for repayments but instead restructured the facility until the market recovered. Fortunately, fate was on his side. When prices recovered, the only steel available in the market was from Devki; all the competitors had cleaned out their stocks because they had been selling their product cheaply to force Devki out. “I woke up one day and I was the only one with steel in the store. I got a good profit margin at that time because I had the goods and nobody else had it”. He made a cool US$1 million in profit.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "Today, Devki is the largest steel firm in the region, with a production capacity of a quarter million tonnes per year spread over several factories. The firm employs over 4,000 employees directly and tens of thousands indirectly and, according to FORBES magazine, Raval is one of the richest men on the continent, with a net worth of some US$400 million. The Devki group has a turnover of Kshs65 billion according to FORBES. The company makes over 300 items, ranging from shoe nails, roofing sheets, steel bars, wire mesh, barbed wire among others. The company also makes its own oxygen on site. “It was very nice of KCB Bank what they did to me. That’s why till today, I tell my board of directors that we will not ever leave KCB Bank because they understand the Kenyan market, they understand the people, and the business way of Kenya. I have stopped doing business with many other banks, but I will never leave KCB Bank,” says Raval.", "type": "text"}]}, {"type": "paragraph", "attrs": {"textAlign": "left"}, "content": [{"text": "The Devki Group has also invested heavily in cement, aviation and energy, partly through financing from KCB Bank Kenya. The group owns National Cement Company, the makers of the Simba Cement brand.
